conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, and C, and we need to predict which container (D or E) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
Liquid flows from the top points A, B, and C.
The liquid from A is blue, from B is orange, and from C is pink.

premise: The blue liquid from A and the pink liquid from C meet and merge.
conclusion: Streams from A and B both land on the green baffle, they merge and flow to the left. The stream from C falls on the right edge of that same baffle and is deflected to the right.

premise: The merged blue and pink liquid flows downward, combining with the orange liquid from B.
conclusion: Streams from A and B merge on the slanted cyan baffle; the combined flow then splits at the bottom, with part entering container D on the left and part entering container E on the right. The stream from C continues along its own baffle and also falls into container E.

premise: The mixed liquid flows into the containers at the bottom.
conclusion: Most of the combined flow from A and B ends up in container D with a small portion of C joining; conversely, container E receives most of the flow from C with a small portion from A and B.
